abstracts.cdata!:
This is a completion report of the
            Second Livestock Development Project in Honduras for which
            credit was approved on October 9, 1973. The credit was
            closed in December 1979 after a delay of one year. The final
            disbursement was made on January 1980 and the credit was
            fully disbursed. Lessons and other points of interest are:
            medium size dairy production requires better quality
            management than small scale operations. The difficulties
            associated with departure from the widely used dual purpose
            (dairy/beef) system towards specialization were
            underestimated at appraisal. The new technologies that were
            adopted by beneficiaries are well suited to conditions in
            Honduras at present. These are dual purpose production using
            cross-bred cattle, with feeding based on rotationally grazed
            pastures with some fodder grown as stand-by feed for the dry
            season, and use of hand labor for milking and weed control.
            During project execution the basis was laid for a full scale
            monitoring and evaluation system and, by using data
            processing equipment, this will also serve all other
            projects which are managed by the project unit. The wide
            spread participation of public and private banks in project
            implementation indicates that the lending terms, such as
            spread, rediscounting margin, adequate lending rate of
            interest associated with rigorous promotion, were
            appropriately designed to attract participation of the whole
            banking sector in financing long-term agriculture development.
